{{Infobox Politician | name = Mikheil Makharadze | image = | caption = | office = Chairman of the Supreme Council of Adjara | term_start = July 20, 2004 | term_end = October 28, 2012 | predecessor = [[Aslan Abashidze]] | successor = [[Avtandil Beridze]] | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1946|11|13|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Batumi]], [[Adjara]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] | party = [[United National Movement (Georgia)|United National Movement]] | residence = [[Batumi]], [[Adjara]] | alma_mater = [[Tbilisi State University]] | occupation = [[Politician]], [[history of philosophy|historian of philosophy]] | religion = | website = [http://www.sca.ge/ www.sca.ge] }} '''Mikheil Makharadze''' ({{lang-ka|მიხეილ მახარაძე}}) (born November 13, 1946) is a [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] politician and [[history of philosophy|historian of philosophy]], who was the Chairman of the [[Supreme Council of the Autonomous Republic of Adjara]] from July 20, 2004, to October 28, 2012.
==Education and academic career== Born in a teacher's family in the [[Khulo district]], [[Adzhar ASSR|Adjara, an autonomous republic]] of then-[[Georgian SSR|Soviet Georgia]], Makharadze graduated from the [[Tbilisi State University]] with a degree in philosophy in 1970. Since then he has been working for the [[Tbilisi]]-based Institute of Philosophy, now part of the [[Ilia State University]]. In 2000, he became a professor at the Tbilisi State University. He has published several works on the history of philosophy, particularly focusing on the [[Dionysius the Areopagite|Areopagite]], medieval Georgian, and [[Renaissance philosophy|Renaissance]] philosophy. From 1986 to 2010, Makharadze oversaw the publication of a 4-volume history of the Georgian philosophical thought, for which he received the National Prize of Georgia (2011).<ref name="sca">{{ka icon}} [http://www.sca.ge/index.php?lang_id=geo&sec_id=123 The Chairman's Biography]. Supreme Council of the Autonomous Republic of Adjara. Accessed April 15, 2012.</ref>
==Political career== Makharadze was a regular contributor to the Georgian political press since the 1990s. In 2003, shortly after the [[Rose Revolution]] in Georgia, he co-founded and co-chaired the political movement ''chveni adjara'' ("Our Adjara"), which opposed the regime of the Adjarian strongman [[Aslan Abashidze]]. In February 2004 he became a member of the [[Parliament of Georgia]] and in June he was elected to the Supreme Council of Adjara, a regional legislature reelected after [[2004 Adjara crisis|Abashidze's resignation]].<ref name="sca"/> Makharadze was elected a chairman of the Supreme Council on July 20, 2004. He was the only candidate for this position as the other one, also a member of the anti-Abashidze movement, [[Koba Khabazi]], had earlier withdrawn his nomination.<ref>[http://civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=7456 Chairman of Adjarian Parliament Elected]. [[Civil Georgia]]. July 20, 2004.</ref> He was reelected to this position on December 2, 2008.<ref>[http://civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=20055 Adjara's Local Parliament Convened]. Civil Georgia. December 2, 2008.</ref> After the [[Adjara legislative election, 2012|October 1, 2012 election]], he was succeeded by [[Avtandil Beridze]] on October 28, 2012.<ref>[http://en.trend.az/regions/scaucasus/georgia/2081252.html Avtandil Beradze elected Chairman of Supreme Council of Adjara]. Trend. October 28, 2012.</ref> Makharadze himself was elected to the Parliament of Georgia on a [[United National Movement (Georgia)|United National Movement]] ticket.
==Personal life== Makharadze is married, with 4 children and 6 grandchildren. He has received several [[Orders, decorations, and medals of Georgia|civil and academic awards]], including the State Prize of Georgia (2004), Order of Honor of Georgia (2004), [[Orders, decorations, and medals of Georgia|Order of Vakhtang Gorgasali]], 1st Rank (2007), Shalva Nutsubidze Prize (2009), and Presidential Order of Excellence (2012).<ref name="sca"/>

{{Infobox academic |honorific_prefix= [[The Reverend]] |name=Morwenna Ludlow |honorific_suffix= |birth_date= {{birth year and age|1970}} |birth_place= |death_date= |death_place= |nationality=British |spouse= |parents= |alma_mater=[[University of Oxford]] |thesis_title= |doctoral_advisor=[[Keith Ward]] |discipline=[[Theology]] |sub_discipline= |workplaces=[[University of Exeter]] |notable_works=Gregory of Nyssa, Ancient and (Post)modern }}
'''Morwenna Ann Ludlow''' (born 1970) is a British historian, theologian, academic, and [[Anglican]] priest, specialising in [[historical theology]]. She is Professor of Christian History and Theology at the [[University of Exeter]] and Head of the Theology and Religion Department. She is known in particular for her work on [[Gregory of Nyssa]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://humanities.exeter.ac.uk/theology/staff/ludlow/|title=Professor Morwenna Ludlow {{!}} Theology and Religion {{!}} University of Exeter|website=humanities.exeter.ac.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-08-16}}</ref>
==Early life and education== Ludlow studied [[Literae humaniores|Literae Humaniores]] at the [[University of Oxford]] and remained there to study for a [[Doctor of Philosophy|D.Phil.]] in [[Theology]] with a dissertation about universal salvation in [[Gregory of Nyssa]] and [[Karl Rahner]]. Ludlow began work on her D.Phil. at [[Trinity College, Oxford|Trinity College]] but moved to [[The Queen's College, Oxford|Queen's College]] on receipt of a Holwell Studentship, and moved again to [[St John's College, Oxford|St John's College]] to take up a Junior Research Fellowship.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=5yYTDAAAQBAJ&pg=PR7&lpg=PR7&dq=%22Morwenna+Ludlow%22+st+john's+college+oxford&source=bl&ots=Dit3KmISw_&sig=dqcuZIjDaHBVW7FKAW0CgPnE2pQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjCrvahw_HcAhXqDMAKHbIABrcQ6AEwAnoECAgQAQ#v=onepage&q=%22Morwenna%20Ludlow%22%20st%20john's%20college%20oxford&f=false|title=Universal Salvation: Eschatology in the Thought of Gregory of Nyssa and Karl Rahner|last=Ludlow|first=Morwenna|date=2000-12-07|publisher=Clarendon Press|isbn=9780198270225|language=en}}</ref>
==Academic career== Ludlow worked at [[Wolfson College, Oxford]] and [[Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge]] before moving to the [[University of Exeter]]. In 2006 Ludlow was appointed as lecturer in [[Patristics]] in the Department of Theology and Religion, [[University of Exeter]]. She was appointed [[Professor (highest academic rank)|Professor]] of Christian History and Theology in 2016. She delivered her inaugural lecture on the 3 November 2016 on ''The Workshop: Experiments in History and Theology''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.history.ac.uk/ehsoc/about/morwenna-ludlow-0|title=Professor Morwenna Ludlow {{!}} Ecclesiastical History Society|website=www.history.ac.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-08-16}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://humanities.exeter.ac.uk/theology/news/title_550481_en.html|title=University of Exeter|last=Robinson|first=Debbie|website=humanities.exeter.ac.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-08-16}}</ref>
Ludlow works primarily on [[patristics]], in particular the work of the fourth-century [[Cappadocian Fathers|Cappadocian]] theologian, [[Gregory of Nyssa]]. Ludlow uses her research into early Christian thought to examine modern theology by analysing the reception of patristic theology by modern writers. She also works on the history of [[eschatology]] in Christianity, with a focus on the idea of universal salvation.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.oxfordpatristics.com/directors|title=patristics {{!}} directors|website=patristics|language=en|access-date=2018-08-16}}</ref>
Ludlow is currently working on the aesthetic qualities and doctrinal content of 4th century Greek Christian texts through a project, ''Art, Craft and Rhetoric.'' In this work, Ludlow uses [[Arts and Crafts movement|arts and crafts]] theorists from [[John Ruskin|Ruskin]] and [[William Morris|Morris]] up to the present-day in order to re-examine early Christian texts.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
Ludlow appeared on BBC Radio 4's ''[[In Our Time (radio series)|In Our Time]]'' on 4 March 2018) to discuss the conversion of Augustine of Hippo to Christianity in a programme with Kate Cooper and Martin Palmer.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b09tyzvz|title=Augustine's Confessions, In Our Time - BBC Radio 4|website=BBC|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-08-16}}</ref>
==Ordained ministry== Ludlow was [[ordained]] in the [[Church of England]] as a [[Deacon#Anglicanism|deacon]] in 2015 and as a [[Priest#Anglican or Episcopalian|priest]] in 2016.<ref name="Crockford">{{Crockford| surname = Ludlow | forenames = Morwenna Ann | id = 47299 | accessed = 11 November 2018}}</ref> She is a [[Curate]] at [[Exeter Cathedral]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.exeter-cathedral.org.uk/about-us/our-people/cathedral-clergy/|title=Cathedral Clergy - Exeter Cathedral|work=Exeter Cathedral|access-date=2018-08-16}}</ref> Since October 2018, she has also served as [[canon theologian]] of the cathedral.<ref>{{cite news |title=Appointments |url=https://www.churchtimes.co.uk/articles/2018/26-october/gazette/appointments/appointments |accessdate=11 November 2018 |work=Church Times |date=26 October 2018}}</ref>
== Selected publications ==
* ''Gregory of Nyssa, Ancient and (Post)modern'' (Oxford University Press, 2013)<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://global.oup.com/academic/product/gregory-of-nyssa-ancient-and-postmodern-9780199677986?cc=us&lang=en&|title=Gregory of Nyssa, Ancient and (Post)modern|date=2013-05-19|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780199677986|location=Oxford, New York}}</ref> * ed. with Scot Douglass ''Reading the Church Fathers'' (Bloomsbury Publishing, 2011)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomsbury.com/us/reading-the-church-fathers-9780567607621/|title=Reading the Church Fathers|last=Bloomsbury.com|website=Bloomsbury Publishing|language=en|access-date=2018-08-16}}</ref> * ''Universal Salvation: Eschatology in the Thought of Gregory of Nyssa and Karl Rahner'' (Clarendon Press, 2000)<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ludlow|first=Morwenna|date=2000-12-07|title=Universal Salvation: Eschatology in the Thought of Gregory of Nyssa and Karl Rahner|url=http://www.oxfordscholarship.com/view/10.1093/0198270224.001.0001/acprof-9780198270225|language=en-US|doi=10.1093/0198270224.001.0001/acprof-9780198270225}}</ref>
== External links ==

{{Infobox | above = Mława riot | image = [[File:Z łysej góry - panoramio.jpg|300px]] | caption = Photograph of the Mława town centre {{OSM Location map |coord={{Coord|53.1194|20.3693}} |float=center |zoom=16 |width=300 |height=220 |scalemark=40 |shape1=n-circle |shape-color1=red |shape-outline1=white |mark-size1=16 |label1=ulica Piłsudskiego |mark-title1=ulica Piłsudskiego |mark-coord1={{Coord|53.11955|20.3692}} |label-pos1=top |label-size1=12 |label-color1=black |mark-coord2={{Coord|53.11945|20.3690}} |label2=ulica Morawskiej |mark-title2=ulica Morawskiej |label-pos2=bottom |fullscreen-option=1 |caption = Location of fatal [[hit-and-run]] accident involving a Roma driver }} | label1 = Damages | data1 = Homes of the [[Romani people in Poland|Romani citizens]] of [[Mława]] }} The '''Mława riot''', or Mława incident,<ref name="Napierski">{{cite web |url=http://www.stowarzyszenie.romowie.net/index.php/czytnik-aktualnosci/items/wywiad-z-romanem-kwiatkowskim-w-glosie-mlawy.html |title=Mławski incydent dał nam doświadczenie na przyszłość |publisher=Stowarzyszenie Romow w Polsce (Roma Society of Poland, homepage) |work=Wywiad z Romanem Kwiatkowskim (Prezesem Stowarzyszenia Romów w Polsce) w "Głosie Mławy" (Interview with Roman Kwiatkowski, President of the Roma Society of Poland) for the "Voice of Mlawa" magazine |date=30 June 2011 |format=reprint |accessdate=13 August 2014 |author=Krzysztof Napierski |trans-title=The Mlawa incident gave us experience for the future}}</ref> also described by Western commentators as the Mława pogrom,<ref>{{cite book |last1=Emigh |first1=Rebecca Jean |last2=Szelényi |first2=Iván |title=Poverty, ethnicity, and gender in Eastern Europe during the market transition |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=O_tXHTK2kQUC&pg=PA101&dq=%22were+a+few+pogroms+and+attacks+against+Roma+in+Poland%22&hl=en&ei=0AA-Tf-3J4OYhQfK1pGeCg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCQQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22were%20a%20few%20pogroms%20and%20attacks%20against%20Roma%20in%20Poland%22&f=false |accessdate=2011-01-24 |year=2001 |publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group |isbn=978-0-275-96881-6 |pages=101–102}}</ref> was a series of violent devastations and looting incidents on 26–27 June 1991 when a group of youth estimated at 200 individuals including young females invaded the homes of [[Romani people|Roma]] residents of the Polish town of [[Mława]] causing them to flee.<ref name="Napierski"/> Not a single Roma person was injured in the riot,<ref name="Napierski"/> but the material losses were substantial affecting up to 40% of residences.<ref name="Napierski"/> Many perpetrators were arrested on-site; a number of them sentenced to jail after a trial.<ref name="Napierski"/> The violence, described by foreign media as motivated by racism and jealousy, received editorial condemnation.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/25/world/poles-vent-their-economic-rage-on-gypsies.html?src=pm |title=Poles Vent Their Economic Rage on Gypsies |date=July 25, 1991 |work=The New York Times |accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20610FD3C5D0C7A8EDDAE0894D9494D81 |title=Hooligans and the Neighbors' Cow |date=July 29, 1991 |work=New York Times |accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref> The incident that triggered the riot was the killing of a Polish pedestrian struck along with his companion in a hit-and-run by a Romani male driver.<ref name="Napierski"/>
==Background== The immediate cause of the riot was a [[hit-and-run]] accident just before midnight on 23 June 1991 on the pedestrian crossing at Piłsudskiego and Zuzanny Morawskiej streets.<ref name="Napierski"/> A speeding luxury car driven by seventeen-year-old Roman Packowski of [[Romani people|Romani ethnicity]] hit and seriously injured two young pedestrians, killing one of them.<ref name="Napierski"/> The driver fled the scene and hid from the police.<ref name="Napierski"/> He was later convinced by the Roma elders to turn himself in.<ref name="Napierski"/> Soon after the accident the local radio station informed that the driver had fled the scene. This claim was in fact true;<ref name="cbos">Anna Giza-Poleszczuk i Jan Poleszczuk, "Cyganie i Polacy w Mławie konflikt etniczny czy społeczny?" prepared for [[CBOS]], Warszawa, December 1992, pages 24 to 29</ref> however, the driver fled after people who witnessed the accident already identified his vehicle.<ref>Beata Klimkiewicz (7 December 1999), [http://www.errc.org/cikk.php?cikk=1127 The pogrom in Mława, Poland: no media influence on justice.] ERRC.org</ref> For the next two days the driver and his car were hidden among the local [[Romani people|Roma community]].<ref name="Napierski"/><ref name="cbos"/>
The accident victim who died from his injuries was the 21-year-old Jaroslaw Pinczewski. The mayor of Mława, Adam Chmielinski informed that he died at the scene.<ref name="Napierski"/> Other victim, seventeen-year old Katarzyna Zakrzewska, suffered permanent physical incapacitation.<ref>{{cite book |last=Cahn |first=Claude |editor=Claude Cahn |title=Roma rights: race, justice, and strategies for equality |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=y8E9u2aD4fYC&pg=PA119&dq=%22in+the+Polish+town+of+Mlawa%22&hl=en&ei=nZVATeGCHImChQeCo9DzCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22in%20the%20Polish%20town%20of%20Mlawa%22&f=false |accessdate=2011-01-26 |series=Sourcebook on contemporary controversies |year=2002 |publisher=IDEA |isbn=978-0-9702130-6-8 |page=119}}</ref>
==Events== Two days later some sixty Mława youths targeted and destroyed the house of a local Roma leader. The assailants quickly grew in number and began burning other Roma homes. Estimates put the number of participants in the violence from one hundred to two hundred.<ref>{{cite book|last=EU Accession Monitoring Program|first=|title=Monitoring the EU accession process: minority protection : country reports|url=https://books.google.com/books?ei=LVZATdD3JqSShAfnvpCSCA&ct=result&id=8-IVAQAAIAAJ&dq=MLAWA+poland+romanies&q=MLAWA+#search_anchor|accessdate=2011-01-27|series=Monitoring the EU accession process |volume=1|year=2001|publisher=Central European University Press|location=Budapest|isbn= 978-1-891385-19-3|page=380}}</ref> Some Roma found protection at the local police station. Others hid at the homes of their Polish friends.<ref name="Napierski"/> A total of 17 Roma houses were seriously damaged and further 4 houses and 9 apartments were vandalized, but no members of the Roma community were hurt. The crowd apparently targeted wealthier Roma and their estates. The police brought in additional forces and imposed a [[curfew]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.errc.org/cikk.php?cikk=1127|title=When the media make a difference: Comparing two European race crimes|last=Klimkiewicz|first=Beata|date=7 July 2004|publisher=[[European Roma Rights Centre]]|pages=''The pogrom in Mlawa, Poland: no media influence on justice''|accessdate=27 January 2011}}</ref>
A former political dissident [[Adam Michnik]] writing in ''[[Gazeta Wyborcza]]'' castigated the police and political authorities for their alleged inaction. The paper also demanded 'official action against ethnic hatred'. As a result, a number of political parties and academic institutions belatedly condemned the pogrom.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=y8E9u2aD4fYC&pg=PA120&dq=%22was+the+only+paper+to+advocate+official+action+against+ethnic+hatred%22&hl=en&ei=C-JATYW9MpK5hAfewfmZCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCQQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22was%20the%20only%20paper%20to%20advocate%20official%20action%20against%20ethnic%20hatred%22&f=false Cahn (2002) p.120]</ref>
The eruption of ethnic violence at Mława in 1991 has been described as 'the renewal of anti-Gypsy racism in Poland' by hostile foreign critics; presumably linked to a significant rise in Polish Roma [[Asylum seeker|asylum applications]] in the [[United Kingdom]]<ref>{{cite book|last=Acton|first=Thomas Alan|title=Gypsy politics and Traveller identity |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Qr3pF8qyS_AC&pg=PA109&dq=%22In+1991+a+pogrom+at+Mlawa%22&hl=en&ei=CqFATeP6IIKyhAfk19ynBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCQQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22In%201991%20a%20pogrom%20at%20Mlawa%22&f=false|accessdate=2011-01-27|year=1997|publisher=Univ of Hertfordshire Press|isbn=978-0-900458-75-0|page=109}}</ref> and [[Sweden]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Drobizheva |first=L. M. |title=Ethnic conflict in the post-Soviet world: case studies and analysis |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KjXvqzUyZ1cC&pg=PA316&dq=MLAWA+poland+romanies&hl=en&ei=LVZATdD3JqSShAfnvpCSCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCkQ6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=mlawa&f=false|accessdate=2011-01-27 |series=Armenian Research Center collection |year=1996|publisher=M.E. Sharpe |isbn= 978-1-56324-740-8 |page=316}}</ref>
Afterwards, 21 persons were brought to court, and 17 were sentenced for up to 30 months in prison. The President of the Roma Society of Poland, Roman Kwiatkowski informed that the relations between the local Roma and their Polish neighbours twenty years after the fact are good.<ref name="Napierski"/>

The '''New Cross house fire''' was a [[conflagration|fire]] that occurred during a party at a house in [[New Cross]], south-east [[London]], in the early hours of Sunday, 18 January 1981. The blaze killed thirteen young people aged between 14 and 22, and one survivor committed suicide two years later.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2004/feb/03/ukcrime.owenbowcott |title=Inquest begins into 14 victims of 1981 fire |last1=Bowcott |first1=Owen |date=3 February 2004 |website=The Guardian |publisher=Guardian News and Media |access-date=8 August 2016}}</ref>
No one has ever been charged in connection to the fire, which forensic science subsequently established was started from inside the house, either by accident or deliberately.
==Circumstances== The party was a joint birthday celebration for Yvonne Ruddock (one of the victims of the fire) and Angela Jackson (who survived) and was held at No. 439, New Cross Road. It began on the evening of Saturday, 17 January 1981 and continued throughout the night and into the early hours of Sunday.<ref>Alexis Akwagyiram, [http://www.bbc.co.uk/caribbean/news/story/2011/01/110118_birth_black_britain.shtml "Did the New Cross fire create a black British identity?"], BBC News, 18 January 2011.</ref>
At the time, there was a fairly high degree of racial tension in the area and [[Far-right politics|far-right]] groups including the [[British National Front|National Front]] were active locally.
There had also been some early complaints from neighbours about excessive noise from the party.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/january/18/newsid_2530000/2530333.stm|title=1981: Nine die in New Cross house fire|date=1981|access-date=2018-05-26|language=en-GB}}</ref>
A white [[Austin Princess]] was seen driving away from the fire.<ref name=":0" />
The initial police suspicion was that the party had been fire-bombed, either as a revenge attack or in an attempt to stop the noise; there was also an alternative theory that a fight had broken out, from which the blaze emanated.
Subsequent forensic investigation found that the fire had started in an armchair inside the front-room of the property at 5:40am on Sunday morning and police ruled out the theory that a fight had taken place.<ref>Dee Lahiri, [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2001/may/15/race.london "'I don't think I can die before I find out what happened to my son'"], ''The Guardian'', 15 May 2001.</ref>
==Aftermath and the Black People's Day of Action== One week after the fire, on 25 January, a meeting was held at the Moonshot Club in New Cross, attended by over one thousand people. The meeting concluded with a march to the scene of the fire and a [[Demonstration (people)|demonstration]] there, which blocked New Cross Road for several hours. The New Cross Massacre Action Committee was set up and organised weekly meetings in New Cross, which saw increasing participation as the police investigation announced that there was no evidence of arson and that the fire was believed to be accidental.
The Action Committee organised a "Black People's Day of Action" on 2 March, when 20,000 people marched over a period of eight hours from [[Fordham Park]] to [[Hyde Park, London|Hyde Park]] carrying placards including: "Thirteen Dead and Nothing Said", "No Police Cover-Up" and "Blood Ah Go Run If Justice No Come". One slogan read: "Dame Jill Knight Set The Fire Alight!" — an apparent reference to a controversial speech by [[Jill Knight, Baroness Knight of Collingtree|Dame Jill Knight]], a right-wing member of the ruling [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative party]], which was widely interpreted as condoning or even encouraging "direct action" against noisy parties.<ref>Darcus Howe, [https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2011/jan/17/new-cross-fire-we-cant-forget "New Cross: the blaze we cannot forget"], ''The Guardian'', 17 January 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/kurtbarling/2011/01/ "New Cross fire - a turning point?"], Barling's London, BBC, 18 January 2011.</ref>
The march was overwhelmingly peaceful but ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'' newspaper reported it with the headline: "Day the blacks ran riot in London". References in other newspapers were typically cursory mentions. None of the reports mentioned the fact that the march was cut in two at [[Blackfriars Bridge]] by police. This unexplained action created delay, confusion and frustration, and was seen as an attempt to stop the march. It also isolated the stewards and march leaders from the general public who had joined the march at the rear. Press indifference or outright hostility led to an increasing division between some elements of the black and white communities.
A survivor of the fire, Anthony Berbeck, apparently committed suicide on 9 July 1983 by jumping from the balcony of a block of council flats in south London. He had been traumatised by the death of his friends in the blaze.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/london/3479827.stm "Eyewitnesses describe killer fire"], BBC News, 11 February 2004.</ref>
==Inquests== The [[inquest]] into the deaths of the 13 teenagers saw criticism of the police. The [[coroner]]'s summary for the jury was heavily directed towards suggesting the fire was accidental, and the jury returned an [[open verdict]] which implied agreement. The victims' families challenged the procedure and while the [[High Court of Justice|High Court]] agreed that the summing-up was inaccurate, it did not overturn the verdict.
In 2002 a new action in the High Court led to an order for a second inquest, which was held in 2004,<ref>Terri Judd, [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/23-years-on-new-inquest-opens-into-black-youths-killed-in-fire-5354285.html "23 years on, new inquest opens into black youths killed in fire"], ''The Independent'', 3 February 2004.</ref> This second inquest also resulted in an open verdict.
==Commemoration== The deaths in the fire were commemorated in a number of reggae songs and poems at the time, including [[Johnny Osbourne]]'s "13 Dead and Nothing Said", [[Benjamin Zephaniah]]'s "13 Dead" and [[Linton Kwesi Johnson]]'s "New Crass Massakah".
On 14 January 2011 an event called "Remembering the New Cross Fire 30 Years On" was held at the [[Albany Theatre]] in [[Deptford]]. The event was hosted by [[Kwame Kwei-Armah]] and was an evening of spoken word, film, discussion and [[Lovers rock]] music. It featured contributions from [[Alex Pascall]], Professor [[Gus John]], filmmaker [[Menelik Shabazz]], spoken-word artists El Crisis and Zena Edwards, novelist [[Courttia Newland]] and musicians [[Janet Kay]] and [[Carroll Thompson]]. Many of the victims' families and the survivors attended the event.<ref>Hugh Muir, [https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/jan/11/hideously-diverse-britain-new-cross-tragedy "Hideously diverse Britain: Memories of the New Cross tragedy never fade"], ''The Guardian'', 11 January 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.thealbany.org.uk/event_detail/602/Events/Remembering-the-New-Cross-Fire "Remembering the New Cross Fire"], The Albany, January 2011.</ref>
St. Andrew's church in [[Brockley]] has a strong connection with the victims as many of them attended the youth club there. In October 2002, Lewisham council installed a special stained-glass window at the church in their memory. On 16 January 2011 a memorial service was held there, with speakers including George Francis, chair of the New Cross Fire Parents' Committee; Lewisham council leader [[Steve Bullock (British politician)|Steve Bullock]]; and [[Joan Ruddock]], MP for Lewisham Deptford.
The victims were also commemorated in January 2011 with a blue plaque from Nubian Jak Community Trust. There is a stone memorial in [[Fordham Park]], Deptford, listing those who died; facing the stone memorial is a bench with a memorial inscription. Both were installed in 2012.
There is also a memorial to the victims consisting of a park bench plus 13 trees with a plaque at either end on [[Hackney Downs]] in east London and a memorial plaque on the wall of Catford Civic Hall listing the names of the "fourteen young people who died in the New Cross Fire of 18th January 1981".
In 2017, the '13 Dead, Nothing Said'<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ypfcqyj-FiM&feature=youtu.be] '13 Dead, Nothing Said' exhibition at Goldsmiths - Exhibition video</ref> exhibition was hosted at Goldsmiths College, University of London. The exhibition<ref>[https://www.gold.ac.uk/calendar/?id=10585] Exhibition notes by Professor Les Back </ref> presents a body of photographs taken by Vron Ware documenting the Black People’s Day of Action on 2 March 1981. The images bear witness to an historic moment of community organising and resistance in post-war Britain.
==Cultural references== *The deaths in the fire were commemorated or mentioned in a number of reggae songs and poems at the time, including [[Johnny Osbourne]]'s "13 Dead and Nothing Said", [[Benjamin Zephaniah]]'s "13 Dead", [[Linton Kwesi Johnson]]'s "New Crass Massakah" and [[UB40]]'s "Don't Let It Pass You By". * The lyrics of [[Carter the Unstoppable Sex Machine|Carter USM's]] 1992 song "The Only Living Boy in New Cross" can be read as a reference to the fire. * Rex Obano's radio play ''Lover's Rock'' (BBC Radio 3 - broadcast November 2012) is a fictional account of the events leading up to the New Cross Fire.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b01nt18q|title=Lover's Rock, Drama on 3 - BBC Radio 3|website=BBC}}</ref> * In March 2018, poet Jay Bernard's performance work investigating the fire, ''Surge: Side A'', won the 2017 [[Ted Hughes Award]] for new poetry.<ref name="BBC 28 March 2018">{{cite news | title= Jay Bernard wins Ted Hughes new poetry award| url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-43575658| author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->|date= 28 March 2018| website= [[BBC News Online]]|publisher= BBC| accessdate= 8 April 2018 }}</ref><ref name="Guardian 28 March 2018">{{cite news | title= Jay Bernard’s ‘personal and brave’ poetry wins Ted Hughes award |url= https://www.theguardian.com/books/2018/mar/28/jay-bernard-poetry-wins-ted-hughes-award-surge-side-a-new-cross-fire| last= Lea | first= Richard | date=28 March 2018| work= [[The Guardian]] |publisher= [[Guardian Media Group]]| accessdate= 8 April 2018 }}</ref> * The events are referenced in [[The Young'uns]] song 'These Hands' on the album Strangers which won [[BBC Radio 2 Folk Awards]] "Best Album" 2018.

{{More footnotes|date=October 2014}} [[Image:Palaisdesrois.jpg|thumb|right|260px|Palace of the Kings of Majorca]] The '''Palace of the Kings of Majorca''' ([[French language|French]]: ''Palais des Rois de Majorque'', [[Catalan language|Catalan]]: ''Palau dels Reis de Mallorca''), is a palace and a fortress with gardens overlooking the city of [[Perpignan]] in [[Pyrenees-Orientales]], [[Occitanie]], [[France]].
== History == === The Kingdom of Majorca (1276-1349)=== In 1276, [[List of monarchs of Majorca|King]] [[James II of Majorca]] made [[Perpignan]] the capital of the [[Kingdom of Majorca]]. He started to build a palace with gardens on the hill of Puig del rey on the south of the town, the architects were Ramon Pau, Pons Descoll, and Bernat Quer with completion in 1309.
=== Ending the Western Schism === In 1415, the [[Holy Roman Emperor]], [[Sigismund, Holy Roman Emperor|Sigismund of Luxemburg]], organised a European summit in Perpignan, to convince the [[Avignon]] [[Antipope Benedict XIII]] to resign his office and take to an end the [[Western Schism]] through the [[Council of Constance]]. On 20 September 1415, the Emperor met with Pope Benedict XIII at the palace with the King [[Ferdinand I of Aragon]] and the delegations of the Counts of Foix, Provence, Savoy, Lorraine, the embassy of the Roman church for the [[Council of Constance]], and embassies from the Kings of France, England, Hungary, Castille and Navarre. The pope refused to resign and to recognise the Pope that the Council had chosen, clashing with the emperor who left Perpignan on 5 November.
=== The Franco-Spanish wars === Part of the northern wing of the palace was destroyed in a siege in 1502. Following the [[Treaty of the Pyrenees]] in 1659, France gained [[Roussillon]], and proceed to develop the defensive features of the palace.
The [[General Council of the Pyrénées-Orientales]] bought the Palace and the gardens in 1958, to the [[Minister of Defence (France)|Ministry of Defence]] who keeps the [[Vauban]] bastions and 19th century buildings and courts as a garrison.<ref>[http://www.cg66.fr/culture/patrimoine_catalanite/monuments/palais_majorque/index.html] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090414081238/http://www.cg66.fr/culture/patrimoine_catalanite/monuments/palais_majorque/index.html |date=April 14, 2009 }}</ref>
== Architecture == The Palace of the Kings of Majorca is a fortified Palace in the [[Gothic architecture|Gothic style]]. It is organised around three courtyards 60 m square. The first foremen on the site were Ramon Pau and especially Pons Descoyl, very active in [[Perpignan]] and the [[Balearic Islands|Baleares]].
It has two chapels, one above the other: the lower is the ''Queen's Chapel'', while the upper is ''Holy Cross'' with a pink marble door.
Here we have together in the “Great Hall“, the seat of political power, the chapel and the royal residence. The position of the chapel in the heart the royal apartments, opposite the throne room, indicates the importance of the spiritual over the temporal. The plan of the palace was inspired by those of [[Majorca]], and the chapel is like that of the earlier [[Sainte-Chapelle]] in [[Paris]].
The walls, built with uncut stones and bricks bound with mortar, were coated with lime and painted.
Doors, corridors, stairs, armatures and the main towers are all made of cut stone: [[ochre]] stone from Les Fonts, Baixas Blue, Sandstone, Red Marble from [[Villefranche-de-Conflent]], White and Blue Marble from [[Ceret]].<ref>[http://www.cg66.fr/culture/patrimoine_catalanite/monuments/palais_majorque/traduc_anglais.html] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081127050315/http://www.cg66.fr/culture/patrimoine_catalanite/monuments/palais_majorque/traduc_anglais.html |date=November 27, 2008 }}</ref>
== Activities == === Guitares au Palais === The [[Guitares au Palais]], a free three-day guitar [[music festival]], is held in the last weekend of August in the Palace and the gardens.
The festival's art director is Pedro Soler and opens the stage to an eclectic stream of guitar enthusiasts with performances in traditional [[acoustic guitar]], [[flamenco]], [[classical music]], [[gypsy style|gypsy music]], [[pop music]] and [[jazz]].
International guests includes the [[Rosenberg Trio]], Tekamali and [[Paco Ibáñez]] in 2004, [[Montserrat Figueras]], Rolf Lislevand and [[Manolo Sanlucar]] in 2005, [[The National (band)|The National]] and Sergio Lopez in 2006, [[Caetano Veloso]] in 2007, and the Rumberos Catalans, Bernardo Sandoval, [[Peter Finger]] and [[Aaron and Bryce Dessner]] in 2008.<ref>[http://www.cg66.fr/bienvenue/ete66/guitares_palais.html] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080707030214/http://www.cg66.fr/bienvenue/ete66/guitares_palais.html |date=July 7, 2008 }}</ref>

{{refimprove|date=July 2008}} [[File:Schweizer Chronik Etterlin.jpg|thumb|Chronicle's title page]] '''Petermann Etterlin''' was born in [[Lucerne]] as the son of [[Egloff Etterlin]], who served as chronicler of the city of Lucerne from 1427 to 1453.<ref name="müller_397">Müller, p. 397.</ref> Although his parents had destined him for an ecclesiastical career, Etterlin never became a [[clergyman]].<ref name="müller_397">Müller, p. 397.</ref> In 1464, Etterlin was appointed copyist of the city of Lucerne.<ref name="müller_397">Müller, p. 397.</ref>
Etterlin’s military career began in 1468 when he joined the army of the [[Old Swiss Confederacy|Swiss Confederation]] at the siege of [[Waldshut-Tiengen|Waldshut]].<ref name="müller_397">Müller, p. 397.</ref> During a temporary exile from the city of Lucerne, Etterlin furthermore participated in the battles of [[Battle of Grandson|Grandson]], [[Murten]] as well as [[Nancy, France|Nancy]] during the [[Burgundian Wars]] (Müller 397). In 1477, he was moreover involved in a campaign against [[Lorraine (province)|Lorraine]].<ref name="müller_397">Müller, p. 397.</ref>
After his return to his hometown in 1477, Etterlin was appointed the post of chancellor of the city of Lucerne.<ref name="müller_397">Müller, p. 397.</ref> In 1495, after his promotion to the position of chronicler of the city of Lucerne, Etterlin joined the leading French-minded party.<ref name="müller_397">Müller, p. 397.</ref> From 1493 to 1501, Etterlin is reported to have made several journeys to [[France]].<ref name="müller_397">Müller, p. 397.</ref>
Towards the end of his life, Etterlin embarked upon writing his ''[[Chronicle of the Swiss Confederation]]'' (German: ''Kronika von der loblichen Eydtgenossenschaft'').<ref name="müller_397">Müller, p. 397.</ref> According to Müller, Petermann Etterlin died in Lucerne in 1509, only two years after the completion of his monumental work.<ref name="müller_397">Müller, p. 397.</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} *Müller, P. L. “Petermann Etterlin.” ''Allgemeine Deutsche Biographie'' 14 (1881): 397-398.

{{for|the Olympian|Philip Falle (sailor)}} [[File:Pliaque Philip Falle bibliothèque Jèrri.jpg|thumb|Plaque on the original library building in Saint Helier]] '''Philip Falle''' (1656–1742) was a clergyman and historian of [[Jersey]].
==Life== Falle was born in the parish of [[Saint Saviour, Jersey|St. Saviour]] in Jersey. He was the eldest of four brothers, two of whom were killed in battle, and one, as a reward for service in the navy, was appointed first lieutenant of [[Hampton Court]]. Sent to England at a very early age, he was educated, first at a school kept by a [[People of Transylvania|Transylvanian]] in [[Great Queen Street, London]], and afterwards by one Mr. Dalgarno at Oxford. In the winter of 1669 he was entered at [[Exeter College, Oxford]], where his tutor was [[Narcissus Marsh]]; and on Marsh becoming principal of [[Alban Hall]], Falle migrated, and graduated there M.A. in 1676.
He was ordained [[deacon]] by [[Ralph Brideoake]], bishop of Chichester, in the following year, and priest in 1679 by [[Guy Carleton (bishop)|Guy Carleton]], who had succeeded to the see. In 1681 he was presented by [[Sir John Lanier]], then [[governor of Jersey]], to the living of [[Trinity, Jersey|Trinity]] parish in that island. The stipend was £40 per annum; but Falle had inherited a small estate by the death of his father. He also undertook the care of the garrison, which was then without a chaplain.
In 1687 [[Thomas Jermyn, 2nd Baron Jermyn]], who had succeeded Lanier as governor, took Falle back to England as tutor to his only son; and in that occupation he remained through the [[Glorious Revolution]], living for the most part at [[Rushbrooke, Suffolk|Rushbrooke]], Lord Jermyn's country seat, near [[Bury St. Edmunds]]. In 1689 he returned to Jersey, and was translated to the charge of his native parish of St. Saviour. Meantime the [[battle of La Hogue]] had been fought, and the French navy became dispersed, but formidable in maritime depredations. The [[States of Jersey]], of which Falle, as Rector of Saint Saviour, was a member, made an appeal to [[William III of England|William III]] for protection. Taking with him Mr. Durell, the advocate-general of the island, Falle went (6 February 1693) to wait upon his majesty at [[Kensington]]. Aided by Jermyn, and favourably received by [[Charles Sackville, 6th Earl of Dorset]], the delegates pointed out the French danger.
In January 1700 Falle became a prebendary of [[Durham Cathedral]]. In 1709 he resigned his Jersey rectorship, having been collated to the benefice of [[Shenley]], near [[Chipping Barnet|Barnet]]. Falle died at Shenley, 7 May 1742, having never married.
==Legacy== In 1736 he presented to his fellow-islanders his collection of books. With another donation by Canon Dumaresq (died 1805), this benefaction developed into a large library, for which the States provided a building in [[Saint Helier]].
==Works== Falle, as part of his advocacy for the defence of Jersey, wrote the first ''Account of Jersey'' (1694);<ref>''Account of the Isle of Jersey, the greatest of those Islands that are now the only remainder of the English Dominions in France, with a new and accurate map of that Island'', 1694.</ref> in that year he was appointed royal chaplain, and preached a sermon on [[Mary II of England|Queen Mary]]'s death (20 December 1694). Around the same time Falle edited a history of the campaign of the [[battle of Landen]] in the [[Nine Years' War]], by his friend and colleague the [[Edward D'Auvergne]], rector of [[Saint Brélade|St. Brelade]]. His main work is based on materials from his friend [[Jean Poingdestre]]; but Falle was a poor historian.
In 1722 he contributed an account of the [[Channel Islands]] to [[Edmund Gibson]]'s translation of [[William Camden|Camden]]'s ‘''Britannia'',’ and in 1734 brought out an expanded edition of his ''History of Jersey''. Falle also published a few sermons.

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{refimprove|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Philippe de Commynes | image = Commynes-recueil-Arras.jpg | image_size = 200px | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1447 | birth_place = [[Renescure]], [[County of Flanders|Flanders]] | death_date = c. 1511 | death_place = [[Argenton-les-Vallées]], [[Poitou]] | nationality = | other_names = | known_for = | occupation = writer, diplomat, politician }} '''Philippe de Commines''' (or '''de Commynes''' or "Philippe de Comines"; [[Latin]]: ''Philippus Cominaeus''; 1447 – 18 October 1511) was a writer and diplomat in the courts of [[Duchy of Burgundy|Burgundy]] and France.{{cite EB1911|wstitle=Commines, Philippe de|volume=6|page=774}} He has been called "the first truly modern writer" ([[Charles Augustin Sainte-Beuve]]) and "the first critical and philosophical historian since classical times" (''[[Oxford Companion to English Literature]]''). Neither a [[chronicle]]r nor a historian in the usual sense of the word, his analyses of the contemporary political scene are what made him virtually unique in his own time. ==Biography== ===Early life=== [[File:Coat of arms of Philippe de Commines.jpg|thumb|Coat of arms of Philippe de Commines.]] '''Commines''' was born at [[Renescure]] (in what was then the [[county of Flanders]]), to an outwardly wealthy family. His parents were Colard van den Clyte (or ''de La Clyte'') and Marguerite d'Armuyden.Bréhier, Louis. "Philippe de Commines." The Catholic Encyclopedia. Vol. 4. New York: Robert Appleton Company, 1908. 8 July 2008 http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/04163a.htm In addition to being ''[[lord of the manor|seigneur]]'' of Renescure, Watten and Saint-Venant, Clyte became [[bailiff]] of Flanders for the Duke of Burgundy in 1436, and had been taken prisoner at the [[Battle of Agincourt]]. Philippe took his surname from a ''seigneurie'' on the [[Lys River|Lys]] which had belonged to the family of his paternal grandmother, Jeanne de Waziers. His paternal grandfather, also named Colard van den Clyte (d. 1404), had been governor first of [[Cassel, France|Cassel]] and then of [[Lille]]. However, the death of Commines' father in 1453 left him the orphaned owner of an estate saddled with enormous debts. In his teens he was taken into the care of [[Philip the Good of Burgundy|Philip the Good]] (1419–1467), Duke of Burgundy, who was his godfather. He fought at the [[Battle of Montlhéry]] in 1465 and the [[Battle of Brusthem]] in 1467 but in general seems to have kept a low profile. ===Burgundy=== In 1468, he became a knight in the household of [[Charles the Bold of Burgundy|Charles the Bold]], Philip's son who succeeded to the dukedom in 1467, and thereafter he moved in the most exalted circles, being party to many important decisions and present at history-making events. A key event in Commines's life seems to have been the meeting between Charles and [[Louis XI of France]] at [[Péronne, Somme|Péronne]] in October 1468. Although Commines's own account skates over the details, it is apparent from other contemporary sources that Louis believed Commines had saved his life. This may explain Louis's later enthusiasm in wooing him away from the Burgundians. In 1470 Commines was sent on an embassy to [[Calais]], then an English possession. It is unlikely that he ever visited England itself, what he knew of its politics and personalities coming mostly from meetings with exiles, both Yorkist and Lancastrian; these included [[Henry VII of England|Henry Tudor]] and [[Richard Neville, Earl of Warwick|Warwick the Kingmaker]]. He also met King [[Edward IV of England]] during the latter's continental exile and later wrote a description of his appearance and character. Commines was a great favorite with Duke Charles for seven years (going back to when he had still been Count of [[Charolais (county)|Charolais]]). The 19th-century scholar [[Isaac D'Israeli]], recounts that one day, when they came home from hunting and were joking around as was their wont within the "family", Commines "ordered" the prince to remove Commines's boots as if he were a servant; laughing, the prince did so but then tossed the boot at Commines, and it bloodied his nose. Everyone in the Burgundian court started calling Commines "booted head". D'Israeli, in his 1824 ''Curiosities of Literature'', suggests that Commines's hatred for the duke of Burgundy poisoned everything he wrote about him, but comments:
"When we are versed in the history of the times, we often discover that memoir-writers have some secret poison in their hearts. Many, like Comines, have had the boot dashed on their nose. Personal rancour wonderfully enlivens the style... Memoirs are often dictated by its fiercest spirit; and then histories are composed from memoirs. Where is TRUTH? Not always in histories and memoirs!"
===Service of Louis XI=== [[File:Philippe de Commynes Louvre LP 47.jpg|thumb|Commines at prayer]] D'Israeli says Commines so resented his nickname that it was the reason he suddenly left Burgundy and went into the service of the French king, but the financial incentives offered by Louis provide a more than adequate explanation: Commines was still heavily burdened with his father's debts. He fled by night from [[Normandy]] on 7 August 1472, and joined Louis near [[Angers]]. On the following morning, when Duke Charles discovered his servant and god-brother missing, he confiscated all of Commines' property. These were later given to [[Philip I of Croÿ-Chimay]]. [[File:Philippe-de-Commynes-sieur-d'Argenton-et-al-Mémoires-de-messire-Philippe-de-Comines MG 1110.tif|thumb|Engraving of Philippe de Commines]]Louis was generous in making up for those losses. On 27 January 1473 the king wed him to a [[Poitou|Poitevin]] heiress, Hélène de Chambes (d.1532), ''[[lord of the manor|dame]]'' of the ''seigneuries'' of Argenton, Varennes, and Maison-Rouge. When Hélène's sister, Colette de Chambes, was believed to have been poisoned by her aged husband [[Louis d'Amboise]], [[Viscount of Thouars]], in a fit of jealousy over her affair with [[Charles de Valois, Duke of Berry|Charles de Valois]], Louis XI's brother, the king had [[confiscation|confiscated]] most of his properties. Some of these he later gave to Commines for life, including the Princedom of Talmond in [[Poitou]], and the ''seigneuries'' of Berrie, Sables, and Olonne.{{cite web| title = Seigneurs d’Amboise| work = Racines et histoire| publisher = Etienne Pattou| date = 26 February 2008| url = http://racineshistoire.free.fr/LGN/PDF/Amboise.pdf| accessdate = 8 July 2008}} Despite later reverses in the family's fortunes, on 13 August 1504 their only child, Jeanne de Commines (d.1513), made a splendid marriage to the heir of [[Brittany]]'s most powerful family, [[René de Brosse]] [[Count of Penthièvre|comte de Penthièvre]] (d.1524). Through her descendants, Commines would become the ancestor of [[Jean IV de Brosse|Jean, duc de Chevreuse]], of the [[Gouffier]] ''[[List of French peerages|ducs de Roannais]]'', and of [[Louis XV of France|Louis XV]],{{cite web| title = Jeanne de Commines| work = Genealogical database| publisher = Gene Web| url = http://geneweb.inria.fr/roglo?lang=en;i=263041| accessdate = 8 July 2008}} while Jeanne herself became the mother-in-law of [[Anne de Pisseleu d'Heilly|Anne, duchesse d'Étampes]], ''[[maîtresse-en-titre]]'' to King [[Francis I of France]]. As a long-time enemy of [[Duchy of Burgundy|Burgundy]], Louis no doubt valued the inside information Commines was able to provide, and Commines quickly became one of the king's most trusted advisers. [[Jean Dufournet]]'s 1966 study of Commines has shown that the next five years, up to 1477, were the most prosperous from Commines's point of view, and the only ones when he truly had Louis's confidence. After Charles the Bold's death in 1477, the two men openly disagreed about how best to take political advantage of the situation. Commines himself admitted associating with some of the king's most prominent opponents and referred to another incident, in May 1478, when Louis reprimanded him for allegedly being open to bribery. Thereafter, much of his diplomatic work was done in the Italian arena, and he came into contact with [[Lorenzo de Medici]] on several occasions. When Louis began to suffer ill-health, Commines was apparently welcomed back into the fold and performed personal services for the king. Many of his activities during the period seem to have involved a degree of secrecy; he was effectively acting as a kind of undercover agent. However, he never regained the level of intimacy with the king that he had previously enjoyed, and Louis's death in 1483, when Commines was still only in his thirties, left him without many friends at court. Nevertheless, he retained a place on the royal council until 1485. Then, having been implicated in the [[mad War|Orleanist rebellion]], he was taken prisoner and kept in confinement for over two years, from January 1487 until March 1489. For some of that period, he was kept in an iron cage. ===Mémoires=== After his release, Commines was exiled to his estate at [[Dreux]], where he began to write his ''Mémoires''. (This title was not used until an edition of 1552.) By 1490, however, he was recovering his position at court and was in the service of King [[Charles VIII of France]]. Charles never allowed him the privileged position he had held under Louis, and he was once again used as an envoy to the Italian states. However, his personal affairs were still problematic, and his right to some of the possessions given him by Louis was subject to legal challenges. In 1498 (fifteen years after the death of [[Louis XI of France]]), Commines's work was completed (first published in [[1524 in literature|1524]] in Paris), and is considered a historical record of immense importance, largely because of its author's cynical and forthright attitude to the events and machinations he had witnessed. His writings reveal many of the less savory aspects of the reign of Louis XI, and Commines related them without apology, insisting that the late king's virtues outweighed his vices. He is regarded as a major primary source for 15th century European history. The ''Mémoires'' are divided into "books", the first six of which were written between 1488 and 1494, and relate the course of events from the beginning of Commines' career (1464) up to the death of King Louis. The remaining two books were written between 1497 and 1501 (printed in [[1528 in literature|1528]]), and deal with the Italian wars, ending in the death of King [[Charles VIII of France]]. [[File:The deathbed of Philippes de Commines.jpg|thumb|The deathbed of Philippe de Commines.]] Commines' scepticism is summed up in his own words: ''Car ceux qui gagnent en ont toujours l'honneur'' ("For the honours always go to the winners"). Some have disputed whether his candid phrases disguise a deeper dishonesty. Yet at no time does he attempt to present himself as a hero, even when recounting his military career. His attitude to politics is one of pragmatism, and his ideas are practical and progressive. His reflections on the events he has witnessed are profound by comparison with those of [[Jean Froissart|Froissart]], who lived a century earlier. His psychological insights into the behaviour of kings are ahead of their time, reminiscent in some ways of his contemporary, [[Niccolò Machiavelli]]. Like Machiavelli, Commines aims to instruct the reader in statecraft, though from a slightly different viewpoint. In particular, he notes how Louis repeatedly got the better of the English, not by military might, but by political machination. ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== * Philippe de Commynes: The Reign of Louis XI 1461-83, translated with an introduction by Michael Jones [https://web.archive.org/web/20060821105545/http://www.r3.org/bookcase/de_commynes/] * {{Cite book |last=Lawton |first=H.W. |authorlink=Harold Lawton |editor=G. R. Potter |title=The New Cambridge Modern History: I. The Renaissance 1493-1520 |year=1957 |month= |publisher=Cambridge University Press |location=Cambridge |pages=184–185 |chapter=The Arts in Western Europe: Vernacular Literature in Western Europe }} * Philippe de Commynes, ''Mémoires'', ed. J. Blanchard, Geneve, Droz, 2007, 2 vol. * Philippe de Commynes, ''Lettres'', ed. J. Blanchard, Geneve, Droz, 2001 * Joël Blanchard, ''Philippe de Commynes'', Paris, Fayard, 2006 * Cristian Bratu, “''Je, aucteur de ce livre'': Authorial Persona and Authority in French Medieval Histories and Chronicles.” In ''Authorities in the Middle Ages. '''Richard of Hexham''' ([[floruit|fl.]] 1141) was an [[England|English]] [[chronicler]]. He became prior of [[Hexham]] about 1141, and died between 1155 and 1167.<ref>Matthew Strickland, ‘Hexham, Richard of (d. 1155x67)’, ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'', Oxford University Press, 2004.</ref>
He wrote ''Brevis Annotatio'', a short history of the church of Hexham from 674 to 1138, for which he borrowed from [[Bede]], [[Eddius]] and [[Symeon of Durham]]. This is published by [[James Raine]] in ''The Priory of Hexham, its Chroniclers, Endowments and Annals'' (Durham, 1864 to 1865). More important is his ''Historia de gestis regis Stephani ci de bello Standardii'', very valuable for the history of the north of [[England]] during the earlier part of the reign of [[Stephen of England|Stephen]], and especially for the [[Battle of the Standard]].
This history, which is a contemporary one, covers the period from the death of [[Henry I of England|Henry I]] in 1135 to early in 1139. It has been edited for the [[Rolls Series]] by [[Richard Howlett]] in the ''Chroniclers of the Reigns of Stephen, Henry II and Richard I'', vol. iii. (1886); and has been translated by [[Joseph Stevenson]] in the ''Church Historians of England'', vol. iv. (1856).

'''Rolf Hachmann''' (19 June 1917 – 5 June 2014) was a German [[Archaeology|archaeologist]] who specialized in [[prehistory|pre-]] and [[protohistory]]. == Life ==
Hachmann was born in [[Blankenese]], now part of [[Hamburg]], [[Germany]]. He attended school at the ''Reformrealgymnasium'' in [[Blankenese]], where he was instructed by Peter Zylmann, a Frisian prehistorian.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ewetel.net/~norbert.fiks/ostfriesland/seiten/plyt2.html |title=The Plytenberg at Leer |publisher=Ewetel.net |date= |accessdate=2014-06-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030615125222/http://www.ewetel.net/~norbert.fiks/ostfriesland/seiten/plyt2.html |archivedate=2003-06-15 |df= }}</ref> He graduated there in 1937, receiving his ''[[Abitur]]''. After work and military service and escape from imprisonment by English forces, in 1945 he began studies at the [[University of Hamburg]], majoring in [[prehistory|pre-]] and [[protohistory]] under [[Hans Jürgen Eggers]] with minor studies in [[classical antiquity]], German medieval studies, [[folkloristics]], [[ethnology]] and [[geography]]. After seven semesters in mid-1949 he received his doctoral degree with a thesis titled ''"Untersuchungen zur Eisenzeit in Mitteldeutschland" ("Investigations of the Iron Age in Central Germany")''. From 1952-1953, he received a travel stipend from the [[German Archaeological Institute]].
After [[habilitation]] in 1955, he was a ''[[Privatdozent]]'' for pre- and protohistory at the [[University of Hamburg]]. In 1959 he succeeded [[Vladimir Milojčić]] as professor of pre- and protohistory at [[Saarland University]] in [[Saarbrücken]], where he directed the institute from 1959 until 1985. At his initiative, the institute was renamed the Institute for Pre- and Protohistory and [[Near Eastern Archaeology]]. He became a professor emeritus in 1986 and continued his scholarly work until his death in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://saarbruecker-zeitung.trauer.de/Traueranzeige/Rolf-Hachmann |title=Rolf Hachmann |publisher=Saarbruecker-zeitung.trauer.de |date= |accessdate=2014-06-15}}</ref>
== Work ==
He took part in various excavations in Turkey ([[Boğazkale]]) and [[Syria]] ([[Tell Chuera]]), and began work on the [[Tell (archaeology)|Tell]] [[Kamid al lawz]] in [[Lebanon]] in 1963 together with [[Arnulf Kuschke]], professor for [[Old Testament|Old Testament studies]] at the [[University of Mainz]]. He directed this excavation from 1966 until 1981. In 1982, he initiated the excavations near the village of Drama in the [[Yambol Province]] of southeast [[Bulgaria]] together with [[Jan Lichardus]] and [[Alexander Fol]], heading the efforts until his retirement.
His research covers a broad spectrum in both periods and geography. He authored important works on topics which included the [[bronze age]] in central Europe and the archaeology and history of [[Germanic peoples]]. In 1962 together with [[Georg Kossack]] and [[Philology|philologist]] [[Hans Kuhn (philologist)|Hans Kuhn]] he published a study on the ''[[Nordwestblock]]'' ("Völker zwischen Germanen und Kelten") and in 1970 investigated the origins of the [[Goths]] and their presumed original homeland in [[Scandinavia]]. He continued his work after becoming an [[emeritus]] professor at the university. In 1991, he published his studies on the origin and creation of the [[Gundestrup cauldron]]. The excavation results from [[Kamid al lawz]] were published in more than 20 volumes under his direction in the series ''Saarbrücker Beiträge zur Altertumskunde''. Those whose [[doctorate]]s he supervised include the former director of antiquities for the [[Saarland]], [[Alfons Kolling]], the mining archaeologist [[Gerd Weisgerber]] and [[François Bertemes]], professor of prehistoric archaeology at [[Martin Luther University of Halle-Wittenberg]].
Hachmann is a regular member of the [[German Archaeological Institute]] and was also an honorary member of the [[Romanian Academy]] from 1993. On June 30, 2007, the University of the Saarland held a colloquium on the occasion of his 90th birthday.<ref>[http://www.archaeologie-online.de/magazin/nachrichten/view/festkolloquium-zum-90-geburtstag-von-professor-dr-rolf-hachmann/ Celebratory colloquium on Prof. Hachmann's 90th birthday]</ref>
